content.description:
Up Above It is a reasonable route with some questionable gear opportunities.  An experienced trad leader should feel OK, but the placements can be tough to suss out in a few spots.

Start from the ground just down and right of a large plateau of rock that extends into the main Cenotaph corner,

Right to Life

. Climb easy moves up and left onto the plateau and then up and right through a set of cracks. There are a few short cruxes, with the top one being a short move with a wide hand jam for only a few inches, feeling about 5.10b.

Some suspect rock was recently cleaned from the route, and presently it seems mostly solid to me.
content.protection: A standard rack of cams to 3" and a set of nuts.
content.location: Just right of the main Cenotaph corner and the bolted lines, a set of discontinuous thin cracks goes up and right, starting on the ledge and finishing up top.

climbs.name: Stairway to Purgatory
climbs.fa: Mike Endicott and grandkids, pre-2016, (T. Bubb, J. Haas, 2/2016?)

content.description:
Stairway to Purgatory is a moderate route with some reasonable climbing, but it is nothing special. On the right side of the South end of Cenotaph Crag, a few meters to the right of the more obvious route, '

Flaked Out

,' a left-facing corner is the prominent feature.

Climb up into and beyond this to the top of the rock, placing gear wherever possible along the way. Belay off of boulders up top using the rope of cordelettes, and descend via a scramble to the East (shortest option) or up and over the crag to the North, and then West, then back down around to the base.
content.protection:
A single rack of stoppers and cams will do, with 0.5-1" cams being the most important.

A set of very large boulders up top can be slung with cordalettes of the rope for an anchor.
content.location:
At the right side of the South end of Cenotaph Crag, just right of '

Flaked Out

,' Stairway to Purgatory pulls up and left onto a ledge and up into a left-facing corner to the top.

Per

George Bracksieck

: this is in the center of the South face.

content.description: Climb right in the main, enormous dihedral of the crag.  You can stick right next to the left wall the entire way, or take a variation 2' to the right that can be climbed from the same anchor.  The rock is cleaner than it looks.
content.protection: A LONG (25") sling to wrap a horn, larger cams (#3-#4 Camalot) size.  Lots of slings to reach the edge from the good gear placements.

content.description:
This is a challenging, little line with bolts and gear just R of

Ethereal

&

Apparition

.  You can start on Apparition & move R to chase the bolts along the arete here.  It is quite thin at its top.  11b climbers may get a spanking.
content.protection:
Cams to a #4 Friend, bolts, pin, and a 2 bolt anchor.

Per

Andrew Zaslove

: all new hardware went in last month (Oct. 2017), and that makes this super safe (5 bolts) for sport only if one was inclined.
content.location: This lies R of a blackish area and L of an arete.

content.description:
I'm really not sure what the hell is the deal with this route.  Two meandering bolts, some bolts w/o hangers and bolt holes, and poorly placed anchors for easy TR access suggest the equipper might have been high.

Follow the first distinct line (2 bolts) to the right of the giant dihedral corner.  Thin face climbing leads to a right-slanting crack finish.
content.protection:
2 bolts start the climb and then it's nothing until the two bolt anchor at the top.... though you probably can fish something into the top crack, it still will be fairly spicy.  In setting up a TR, be CAREFUL!  the bolts are low on a slopey face.  Best to set it up while anchored in to something or someone secure.

Per

Andrew Zaslove

: the route was cleaned up a bit, and the old bolts (buttonheads) were removed/replaced. THREE bomber bolts now lead to a few small pieces in the upper crack.

climbs.name: Like a Junky Tying Off for the Last Time
climbs.fa: Jason Haas, Tony Bubb, and Emma Salman

content.description: This is a classic route up the corner just above the dead tree. It is deceptively hard.
content.protection: 6 bolts and an anchor with 2 rap rings.
content.location: Start at the bottom of the cliff above the dead tree.

climbs.name: Going Down In it
climbs.fa: S. Levin, free solo, September 1990, F. Knapp, D. Hare, 1991 (2nd)

content.description:
A hard route for the grade, with no pro down low.  It would be easy to get injured slipping off the holds down low, which are surprisingly insecure for such good edges.

There is more protection as you get about 20' up, but that is past the crux anyway.

Down low get into the center area of a broad, black streak and find some good-angled crimpers - set feet and heave up onto higher holds, eventually heading slightly right to the right side of the back streak.  A few small nuts could be placed there, then continue up and left passing a few intermittent cracks and potential placements as you go higher (and the climbing gets easier).

The crux is down low and not really protectable, so consider a TR, which can be done on Camalots up above the climb.

To retreat, belay the second up and walk off, or walk down to some anchors across an edge (to the South) and rap 40-50' to the ledge.
content.protection: There is not much worth placing in the harder climbing down low, a few nuts and small cams higher as the climbing gets easier.  Bring up to a #3 Camalot for an anchor up top for a TR.
content.location: This is the leftmost route on Cenotaph proper, which starts in and follows a black water stain. Te black rock is surprisingly textured and positive, but the holds on smooth horizontal edges are somewhat less frictiony.

content.description:
This is not a bad route. It has an all-too-short section of great flake jamming, with some interesting climbing both above and below that section.

Spot the flake and climb up into that from below, doing the route's crux to reach into those jams. Follow the 2-3" flake up to its top and onto a ledge.  Make less secure (slabby) moves off of the ledge to the top of the rock and put in a belay or directional with a few #3 Camalots.

Scrambling off of this ledge is possible to the East.
content.protection: A set of cams from small to 3" and some slings. Multiple #3 Camalots can be placed in a horizontal at the top for an anchor or directional.
content.location: Flaked Out lies on the very right hand end of the Cenotaph Crag, facing the Cenotaph Spire.  It ascends the jagged looking flake system on the left end of that facet of the wall.

content.description: Follow the lichenous, somewhat crumbly crack system, pulling over a slight bulge near the top.
content.protection: Gear to 3" and a double bolted anchor at the top with rap rings.
content.location:
Start right of Up Above It and the small, short roof extending to its right.  I don't believe this is the wider crack on the far right of the face, which actually looked better from the ground.

Walk off the back of the crag.

content.description:
This is a brief line just right of a blackish section & left of a few bolts on

Apparition

&

Phantasm

.  It's probably worth doing if you are at the crag.  It feels somewhat strenuous for its brief length.  There is a bolt anchor to the right or trees a ways back.
content.protection: Light rack including a few cams.

content.description:
This line lies between

Ethereal

&

Phantasm

on the left side of Cenotaph Crag.  It starts with a couple thin cracks over a bulge, past a bolt, pin, and a bolt. The top is quite thin.  Opposition seems key.
content.protection:
Cams, 2 bolts, 1 pin, 2 bolt anchor.

Per

Andrew Zaslove

: the pin was loose and was removed. The big death block halfway up also fell out. Now there are 4 bolts and a couple pieces in between.
content.location: This is between the blackish area and the arete on the left side of the crag.

content.description: This is a short but fun route up the far left side of the cliff.
content.protection: 5 bolts and an anchor with 2 rap rings.
content.location:
It is left of

Going Down In It

.

content.description: The crux of this short crack is at the bottom in the first 10' of climbing.  It is easier up higher.  This is a better looking crack than 5.8 crack but it still has a lot of lichen on it.  The crack looks more appealing than 5.8 Crack and it has better climbing but it is too short to be a destination route.  It is an all right climb to do as a warm up if you are already at this crag.  There are lots of face holds near the crack.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #4 Camalot.  A #5 Camalot will work but is not necessary.  Build a gear anchor on top.
content.location: This route is the obvious crack on the corner to the right of 5.8 crack.  This is a fist sized crack.  Get down by scrambling to the north.
